nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Let's get started. Our first question tonight is from Aneel James.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Has Tory sleaze returned?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Caroline Lucas.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Yes, it has returned

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , on steroids, I'm afraid.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It really has been shocking to see the way in which Owen Paterson has been defended by the Prime Minister

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: that, in a sense, we've abolished any kind of independent system of dealing with MPs' misconduct

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: and instead we have the prospects of a new committee that was going to be a kangaroo court.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: There was going to be a built-in government majority on the new committee.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: You can't go around changing the rules when you don't like them.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: That's exactly what this prime minister is doing.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It goes much wider, sadly, than just Owen Paterson.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: This is a Prime Minister who cares nothing for standards or dish and the rule of law.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We saw him do something and the rule of law.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We saw him do something something similar when he a on the ground partly.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: He refused to sack priti patel when she was accused of bullying. He himself, of course, is the biggest problem of all.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I have tried myself to find out how you hold the prime minister to account whether he lies, repeatedly.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Let's be very clear this is a prime minister who lies repeatedly

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , systematically.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: The problem is the Judge, jury and courted is all the prime minister.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: There's no way of holding him to account.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: This is a bigger problem than Owen Paterson.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I'm glad he resigned.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It was grotesque to watch Parliament yesterday to see how all thetory MPs were criteria goodness into supporting this amount.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I'm not sure what Paul Scully Paul Scully will think of it

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , but vote for it.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It is extraordinary to see how people can be persuaded for something that is so manifestly wrong.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: So, yes, Tory liaise is back

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: and idle a bad look.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul Scully.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It's not.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We have a situation here where we have to look at the process.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I think if you look at the process that Owen Paterson went through

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , if that came to me as a constituency MP with someone in a different set of circumstances, when he was talking about the fact that it was 17 months, he had 17 witnesses, none of whom were questioned

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , I would want to be able to test that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I would want to have maybe a second structure

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , an appeal system.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We also have -- we actually have two processes.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We all have an independent complaints and grievance scheme that was set up with other issues around bullying, when the previous speaker was accused of bullying.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: That has an appeal system.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: This one doesn't.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Is the government wrong to back down today?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: What I was going to say, that's why I voted about the process.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It is fair that someone should be able to go through that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It did not overturn what the Commissioner for Standards actually found

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: because they would have had that due process

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: and that would have come back whatever the result was.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: But, no, then, obviously, Owen Paterson has forced the issue by resigning.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I think, clearly there was a case to answer

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , absolutely there was a case to answer.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Emily Thornberry.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There is an appeal process.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Let me touch on that for a minute. What happens is if a complaint has been made against you, let's say you received half a million pounds for two companies to lobby for them

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , let's say, as happened with this case, and he goes before an independent commissioner, he then can go before a panel of MPs then can go before the whole of Parliament.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It is important to stick to the truth.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: What happened 25 years ago, obviously, was at the end of a long time of tory government

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: conservatory MPs were taking money in brown envelopes to ask questions on behalf of companies

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , at the end of this long period of a conservative government we havetory MPs taking money again to ask questions and lobby on behalf.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: At least last time they were ashamed.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It is not just conservatives

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , there have been other MPs, clearly, who have brought Parliament into disrepute

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: and we need to have an independent system that can assess what has happened and make sure proper decisions are made.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: We cannot have MPs deciding for themselves.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: The current process we have is one whereby more than half-of the people on the panel are members of the public.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: What happened yesterday was the to use that you are majority and sweep away all of that

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , sweep away all of that do have them make a fundamental change to our constitution

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: and decide they were going to introduce a committee that was going to be dominated by --coronavirus

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , that was com innate by MPs

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , not have any members of the chaired by a Conservative

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: so they could do whatever they wanted.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: That isn't the way we do things in this country.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: We need to have an independent panel

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: and we have to be very careful that, once all the fuss is gone, they don't try to introduce some skewed system that will allow them to do what they like

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: because they are not above the law.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: They are not above the law and they should make sure they stick to the rules like everyone else.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: You cannot, if you are found to have broken the rules, simply decide that you're going to change them.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: That is not the way you behave in this country.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I think, actually, it is a bit disingenuous to say he didn't have the right of appeal.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He was able to take his lawyers in to speak to the committee.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He had 17 written witnesses that he could stake --

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Written statements you mean.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Written statements that that he could take.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: They were about character.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I read the report yesterday.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: They were character references.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: It is like having more witnesses who will say, yes, he might be a burglar but while he was burgling your house he fed the cat.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He's a nice man therefore it doesn't count.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: That's not true.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I think the British public are fed up thinking Boris Johnson thinks he can get his mates after.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: My narrative for this story is that Boris Johnson flew in a private jet down to London, we object to a party, went to meet his friends.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Amongst his friends were people there who persuaded him to get him off, to get Owen Paterson off.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He said "I'll do this".

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: It might not be the true

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: but that's what it is in the general public's mind.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I'm telling you lots of people are saying that.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: My friends are saying that.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: We don't understand what happened yesterday.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: At one point he was saying we should do this

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , by lunchtime today, everything is thrown up in the air and everything is changed.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: What's the truth of it?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Where are the facts in this?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: You mentioned Boris Johnson flying in a private jet.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Were you at that dinner?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: This is very embarrassing.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I was invited

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: but I couldn't get a dog sitter.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: This is why I'm a terrible journalist.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I'm five minutes from where things are happening

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: and I find a reason not to be in the room.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The government backed Owen Paterson, then withdrew the report.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: By doing so it damaged its -- and Owen Paterson.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I think the Prime Minister was motivated by a sense of decency.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: He thought in this instance a man was being unfairly hounded.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Not just for the reasons being given because the process was so long, so opaque and somewhat contradictory.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Not just because the lobbying he was supposed to have done is raising genuine public health questions with ministers, one was related to absence in --

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: He was being paid for that?

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: You don't need to be paid in order to be a whistle-blower.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: There is a third reason, which we have not mentioned

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: because it is too sensitive

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , which is last year Owen Paterson's wife took her own life.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: That's why many felt sympathetic to support this man in this particular instance.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Now the problem is they weren't just supporting a man with one case

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , which they might feel on the merits they can take his side on

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: ; they were also, in doing that, attempting to rewrite the rules.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: And that looks like someone has been found guilty of something and you're trying to get them off by rewriting the rules.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: And by screwing around in the last 48 hours

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , the government has ended up failing on both counts.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It has undermined any case for reform

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: because it looks like reform is a Trojan horse for getting their mate off

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , but they've also done something which led to an MP having to resign

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: even though he insists he is guilty of nothing.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It is a PR disaster.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: But only a few weeks since the death of David Amoss

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , a few weeks ago we were talking about the importance of remembering that MPs are human beings.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It doesn't mean they should be let off things.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Nevertheless, I'm telling you, behind the scenes there is a human context to this story

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: and that's why many MPs felt obliged to support Owen Paterson.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I'm in human resources

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: and we have to deal with issues like this all the time.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I find it very difficult when there's a standards piece and someone is convicted in the court, both MPs, one gets hounded, has to leave, the other can still be an MP.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Why don't we have the same standard for everything

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , when you are convicted of something, you have to leave.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Of course Owen Paterson has not been convicted of anything.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I think the MPs should only be dealing with their constituency issues

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , not taking on multiple roles.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: By taking on multiple roles it is saying the issues within their constituency is a part-time role.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: So I therefore have time to take payment from other companies.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: When you are elected into this particular role for your constituency, you act for them, them alone and nobody else.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Would you include things like being a firefighter or a GP?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I think it can be a good thing that MPs can do things other than be an MP.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: The idea that you're going to have time to be putting in to doing another job on top of your work as an MP I think is for the birds.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I think where you might be right is to have -- where you might be right is we could look at job-sharing for MPs.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: That is something I think would be positive.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: You get a wider selection of people putting themselves forward for that role

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , people who are carers or people who want to keep a foot in the door of being a GP or firefighter, whatever it is.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: But the idea you can find time for a part-time job that's going to pay you on top of being an MP I find preposterous.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: We got a little bit away from the question. Paul, has Tory sleaze returned?

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I am listening with interest. I am only privileged to what I read in the newspapers. But what is clear to me, it is an own goal that has been scored here.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: At a time when we need more trust in our politicians, in any institutions

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , at a time that we need to operate under a higher moral standard

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , I can only conclude that this is a human tragedy but also a political tragedy that should have some lessons.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: You cannot change the game when you are playing the game

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and that seems to be an attempt here to do that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: That is very confusing for the public at large

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and I consider myself to be part of that public at large.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: There is a bigger issue here, though, that has been raised which I actually agree with that to what extent do we let other money come into politics to influence the decisions that need to be taken?

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: In my book Net Positive that just came out, I specifically discussed the $3.5 billion that industry is using to lobby to influence laws. I have a problem with that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I think society at large has a problem with that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: At Unilever I would not allow any of these things to happen, if I may be very clear.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So for individual companies to pay for very specific tasks to be done is something that I think might have been accepted in the public eye a few years ago

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: but should be looked at now in the world that we live in currently.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: My advice to companies would be, who actually pay that money, you're as much part of this problem that we're discussing as the people here that are being talked about.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: A trust items on foot, leaves on horseback.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I think in this case the horses were out

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , and that's regrettable.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: It would be good to provide laws that were broader to cover this.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I would like to decide when the government decided this process needed review.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Was it because of Mr Paterson

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: or is it because the process needs review?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Either way, as the gentlemen just said, once you committed something under one set of rules, you shouldn't suddenly change them.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Change the rules, by all means

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , but do that because you need to change them

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , not because one of your mates has got a problem.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: [ DONE]

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There has been a slow burn on this.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: You can see a pattern of behaviour in relation to this government

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , particularly in relation to the Prime Minister.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: He won't answer questions straightforwardly about how his flat at No. 10 was redecorated, who paid for his holiday in Mustique.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There were his junior ministers.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: We heard about the Home Secretary.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Where there are breaches on the face of it on the rules, nothing seems to happen.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There's a falling out between the government and those who are supposed to be independently applying those rules.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: What is most important is the way they are going to try to undermine judicial review, where the courts can hold government to account.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Our democratic system has a series of checks and balances

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: but at the moment we have a government to whom they feel the law doesn't apply to them.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It is a pattern of behaviour.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: To ask the question put by the man in the sweater there, why decide to change the process, now you aren't able to or the government has changed it's mind.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: This has been in existence since 2013.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I was going to answer that directly. The system has not carried a lot of confidence with it, by complainants and those going through the system itself.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: But there were issues particularly highlighted by this case.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: So, rather than changing the system drastically, rather than seeking to overturn the decision as some have talked about, it was looking to add an extra layer of appeal to be able to sort of test the --

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Why now? The question is why now?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Because of what we've seen.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: When politicians go through these processes they have a massive height to fall from.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We've seen what's happened with the human cost

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , as Tim said, of Owen, who broke his back.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: He was lucky to be able to walk again.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Then went through this process

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , then lost his wife.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: The perspective that is looked on in politicians, I don't think, actually, is often worked through at what cost they're doing some parts of their job.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: But, clearly, there was a case to be answered.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: That's what I'm saying. It wasn't going to overturn the decision but it was going to analyse it further.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: There may be an argument to say look again at this process.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: But the idea that you would do that under a live case is just -- it is just unacceptable.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I sat on the committee that Andrew Ledson chaired looking at the issue of sexual harassment in Parliament and what processes you would need for that.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It took us a year of painstaking cross-party work to come up with a new system, a better system.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: That's the kind of legwork that you had to put in.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: The idea that Jacob Reese Mogg could rock up in Parliament yesterday and say here's a new committee when putting the tories in the driving seat was never going to work.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We need the long-term process to get the better rules in place.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: The last thing I wanted to say to Tim was about this being a case of Boris Johnson showing decency

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , there is a case that Boris Johnson was thinking about his own skin

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: because he knows the commissioner is likely to be looking at him again, about his flat.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: So he's actually got bad blood with this committee.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: For him to be promoting a process that would say she will be pushed out of her role

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: in order for him to be able to carry on with his lackadaisical business as usual --

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: If you throw these around

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: it is damaging politics as a whole.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Absolutely it is.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Time and time again, when people will obviously use this for party political points --

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: The audience are laughing when you say that.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: What do you feel about that?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: The lady at the back is talking about the narrative.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: That's the narrative given by the other parties

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , by the media who are looking at the short-term aspects.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: It is not what you want us to hear.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: This is your story as well, isn't it?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: This man needs to be let off.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: No, absolutely not. It wasn't going to overturn the decision --

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: If it is not going to overturn the decision

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , let it run through.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It was taking a long-term view of his career and that process to give confidence in the process long term.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Forgive me for interrupting. I'm going to move on because there's a massive topic I want to cover this evening. Before I get to it, I want to say next week we will be in Hartlepool as COP-26 comes to a close. We will have Naomi Klein, then the following week we are in Beckenham where we will be joined by Jordan Peterson. If you would like to be in either of those audiences, do apply on the Question Time website. Do come along, we'd love to see you there.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Our next question from Jonathan.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Without the likes of Russia, India and China on board, are this week's COP-26 breakthrough pledges such as the reduction of methane emissions a glimmer of hope or more blah blah blah?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: To quote the words of Greta Thunberg. Paul, not only have you been the head of Unilever for 10 years

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: but you work with the UN as an advocate for sustainability.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: What's your view on this?

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I'm glad we're talking climate change now

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and I'm in Glasgow and not London

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: because the issues in London seem to be more trivial than what we're dealing with here in Glasgow.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: People have discovered the burning issue of climate change

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and we don't have any time any more.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: The question is a pertinent one.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We need the bigger countries like India, China, Russia, 100 percent on board.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: But the situation is actually a little bit better than the question would suggest.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Before COVID started, we have all worried that nobody was serious to stick to the Paris Agreements, to get to the 1.5 degrees. When COVID came everybody said that's a major distraction, we will not spend time on climate change.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: At the time of COVID, 20 percent of the world had agreed to be net 0 by 2050.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We now have 80 percent of the world.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: China, India, Russia have signed up to the 1.5 degree pledge. They are participating in the 100 million financing for emerging markets.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They have signed major declarations on forest reduction and forest restoration.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So all these --

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul, I'm sorry to interrupt. Let me ask you about deforestation.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: You have 110 countries agreeing to reverse it by 2030, then today, Indonesia, who had signed up to that, said hang on a minute, we don't want to be doing that after all.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: That must be disheartening, to say the least.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: India has made a commitment to be net zero by 2070 and on carbon emission by 2050.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Russia has made a commitment with China to be net zero by 2060.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: These countries are there.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They have made commitments and there are mechanics that increasingly are put in place to hold everybody accountable.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: This is the next step that needs to happen.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So we can all speculate on the future of whether or not these countries are doing but, as I said, they are the most affected by climate change.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They have the most interest to ensure the right actions will be implemented.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Coming to independent -- the only country with tropical forests, has seen a rapid decline in deforestation.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They are continuing with that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They put a price of carbon in place.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They have aggressive government policies to continue in that direction

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: because they know the world doesn't want unsustainable palm oil anymore.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They know they are destroying livelihoods of indigenous people if they continue like this.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So the country is actively involved in preserving our natural capital.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: In fact, Indonesia is probably best placed in the future in this world to monetise the enormous natural capital that they have to confer their economy to this greener more sustainable economy.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I'm sorry, Paul, forgive me. I'm going to bring in the rest of the panel. The question is, given that Russia, India and China didn't turn up, how successful are the breakthrough pledges of COP-26, a glimmer of hope or blah blah blah.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The leaders didn't have support

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: but I'm feeling positive about COP, actually.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: What it has done is come up with deadlines and goals

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , but the thing is they push the world in a certain direction.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Once, most catalytically, we begin to invest private capital in the technology, that will develop momentum.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Just because a -- because it's target isn't ambitious or it is a long way off.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It does matter

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , of course, it would be better if it were sooner

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , but because they set the target

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: they are going to develop towards it.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: We run into two problems.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: One is that the developing world is not going to wish to give up growth that the developed world has enjoyed.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: So we have to find some way of handling that.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: An example is the disappointing statement by Indonesia on deforestation, where it said it would be unfair to expect us to keep to these limits.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: When rich countries have developed so fast, why should they limit themselves?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: So it may be the West has to spend more money to assist those countries to go to net zero.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The second problem we come up against is internal.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It is to do the cost of us at home of going green.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It was notable that Joe Biden is trying to persuade OPEC to increase production of oil.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: That's not a good look.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: There is currently a gulf, a gap between our ambition of where we want to be in Britain and where the technology is.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It's not there yet.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It has not been developed

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , it is not quite cheap enough.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: How do we meet that gap between our ambition and where the technology is?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The reality, I expect, is it a reduction in individual consumption and spending a lot more money through taxes, subsidies, increased prices, etcetera, etcetera.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: So I'm waiting for the moment when western governments are a little bit more honest with their public

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: and say to them: If you really want to do this, we can do it, we're making progress, but it is going to cost the consumer a lot of money and it is going to require a change in lifestyle.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: When you put that proposition to the public

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , you might see some consumer resistance.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: The man there.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Good evening. The cost to the consumer, the general public

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , but what about the actual politicians that are attending this conference?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: They're flying from all over the world.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: The American President landed on Air Force One.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He had many limousines to take him to the actual conference.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: How is that helping climate change?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: It doesn't

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: and it's disgusting

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: and the conference should have been as virtual as possible.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: This is my point.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Politicians are going to ask us to make significant sacrifices in the next few years.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: If they are still flying to a climate conference

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: -- by the way, in the middle of a pandemic

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: -- that looks absolutely appalling.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I guess that fish gotta swim and the rich got to fly

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , but if they are trying to persuade us, ordinary people, to adjust our lifestyles to meet their ambitions

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , it is about time they started to do it as well.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: The man at the back there.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: With all the restrictions in 2020 that were put on us by the pandemic, carbon emissions globally fell by 5 percent.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Are we kidding ourselves about the seismic sense that's needed to really reduce carbon levels down?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: We would have to go into some kind of lockdown, is what you are saying?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Caroline, I don't know what your view is about that. You are hearing some optimistic views, are you?

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I think there has been incremental steps forward.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: In terms of trying to measure whether or not you feel optimistic, it feels there are two ways of measuring that.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: On the one hand the world of what's deemed to be currently politically possible

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , and in that world with, yes, the small steps forward are welcome

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , although there are big questions about how the deforestation agreement will be enforced

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , the fact that on the finance agreement it is still not clear whether or not companies are still going to be able to fund fossil fuels

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , it looks as if they are

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , so there are issues there.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: But compared to the transformative change that it requires, and let's not forget what is at stake here, the future of small island states and the rest of us, too

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , then compared to that kind of way of measuring progress we are still a long way off.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I want to challenge some of the language around the sacrifice.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I think one of the most frustrating things about this discussion is the fact that what's possible here is the possibility of a better quality of life for all of us.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It doesn't have to be around sack cloth and ashes.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: This is about the possibility, for example, of having every single home properly insulated.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: A proper house by house, street by street locally authority led programme that gets fuel bills down

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , creates millions of jobs.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: One of my favourite cartoons has a professor in front of a whiteboard.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: On the whiteboard they listed all the advantages of moving to a zero carbon economy, free or affordable public transport, properly insulated homes.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Then there's a student with a speech bubble coming out of their mouths: What if climate change is a hoax and we created a better world for no reason.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: There's a real change of creating that better world

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , and realised that public opinion is miles ahead of government.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: They want bolder action

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , look at every single opinion poll where it is clear that people want to act.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Look at the fact that climate change be acceptable

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: -- come up with far bolder things that governments ever do.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: For those people taking many, many flights, just 15 percent of the population take 70 percent of the flights.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Once you start taking more than one flight in a year that ratchets up.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: People like there -- they want to see a ban on high carbon products being advertised.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: There are some win wins here.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We should be able to talk about those and bringing people with us.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Let's hear from some of these people.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Personal responsibility is important.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Where's the emphasis being placed on corporate responsibility who create the most emissions.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I'll come back to that. Yes, the Woman in the yellow top.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Is given that China and Russia are not admonishing seize how significant is that in those countries for creating change.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: One of the issues I have is the politicians are making these pledges

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , they're not backed by anything

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , they are just weak promises.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: The problem we have is lot of the leaders are using this as a photo opportunity.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: The chancellor brings forward a green budget box.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: A few weeks ago in his budget box, which was a different colour, he was cutting the tax that people pay for domestic flight.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Domestic flights is the worst possible way that you can move around.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: It doesn't join up with the pledges they are making now.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: COP is not a moment in time.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It is a long time getting to this culmination.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: When we took over the presidency there was 20 or 30 percent -- 20 countries, rather, that had adopted a net zero plan.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: They are now up to 90.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We are starting to build up that crescendo.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: We know that Paris was a time to set those targets

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: but now is the time where we are starting to outline what action is going to be taken.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I agree that it's, you know, again the optics of people flying into Glasgow is not particularly good, but what you do find --

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: And the prime minister flying in a private jet to a dinner in London.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: What you find is not so much what's happening in that hall

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , it's what's happening with the negotiating teams alongside those informal meetings.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: When China are not here, for example, there is a high-level negotiating team from China that's over here.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: So do you think -- the question, basically, is it going to be a success or more blah blah blah?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I know we are only part way through it, at the moment is it looking a success.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I'm optimistic.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: There's plenty more to be done, clearly.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: The prime minister is talking about coal, cars, cash and trees.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: All those need to be looked at.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Whether it is deforestation, whether making sure we have 450 of the top financial companies in the world that are aligning their funds, trillions of pounds, dollars worth of funds along with the climate change, the US climate change targets.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: So this is a really important market change.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: But what it is also doing is developing and creating markets.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Tim talked about the cost to the consumer, but the government money and the government strategies that we have also leveraged private money.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: So the hydrogen strategy is bringing in money to this country

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: because they know the government are backing a particular technology and that can start to be developed.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: I think in order to assist whether COP is going to be a success

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , we need to look at other commitments that the countries are making enough and will they stick to them.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: As the gentleman in the blue jacket was saying, I agree with you.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: I do worry that sometimes -- well, we saw it, we saw it, frankly -- I went to the Copenhagen summit.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There was Â£100 billion supposed to be committed by the developed world to the developing world to help them develop in a green way and be able to protect themselves against the effects of climate change. They haven't seen that money.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: So I worry there are countries going we'll be zero by 2070.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: There isn't a plan -- a proper plan as to how they are going to get there.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: And it doesn't really -- I mean, it is great now people are starting to say we want to get to net zero.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: That's different to what they said before.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: They were saying before they didn't need to do it.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: But we need a proper plan showing how we're going to get there

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , how much carbon are they going to produce in the meantime.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Because the truth is, in order to stick to make sure our planet doesn't heat up more than 1.5 degrees we need to half the amount of carbon we are producing by the end of this decade.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Now, how are we going to do that?

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Yes

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , we need to have proper commitments from countries where they mean it

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: and whenever we have international meetings we sit down and say how is your plan?

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: How are you getting on with it

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: and people are held to account.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Yes, we need to spread responsibility to other companies.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It may be that British companies in Britain or perhaps Dutch companies, you know, when they are working in places where there's a lot of regulation, where there's a good media, they may be behaving in a way that they can hold their heads up high

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , but some of those companies are behaving well

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: once they get out of Europe, away from the media, where there are governments that can't or don't regulate or whatever it is, and those companies in those countries are behaving in a blatantly irresponsible way.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: What we need to do is be looking carefully at our supply chains

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , regulate them properly, have a proper vision

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: so we can keep control over the way some companies are behaving around the world.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul Polman, let me come back to you. You're not head of Unilever anymore

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: but I know you talked a lot about corporate responsibility.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: What is your view about some companies not living up to it?

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I agree. We are all in this together.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: The secretary general called It Code Red.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We have to all have a long discussion if these commitments are serious or not

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , but we agreed on a review of that now every two years

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , the emerging markets are asking for an annual review.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I happen to agree with that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: There are clear dates being put in place to see if we can hold people accountable to their commitments.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: If we don't do that

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , we have a serious problem.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: But the issue is this, even with the current commitments, we are far removed from what we really need to stay below 1.5 degrees. We need 20 times more on electric cars.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We're talking here about the biggest transformation of our global economy since the Industrial Revolution

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , which started here in Glasgow, by the way.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Now, coming to the cost. I think for the first time people are starting to realise that the cost of not accounting now is infinitely higher than the cost of acting.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: COVID has shown us that we can't have healthy people on an unhealthy planet.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We have spent 60 trillion to save livelihoods.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: The IMS estimates we lost $27 trillion in the global economy.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Guest what, most of that cost is borne by the people that already kept the wrong stick of society in loading their jobs, losing their lives, in not having a safety net around them.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So governments are starting to understand and businesses are starting to understand this is probably the biggest and best business opportunity that we have in front of us.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: What we see now for a chance is we have enough responsible actions coming up that are making net zero pledges

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , are starting to implement it

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and, in fact, are the ones pushing the government now to the higher ambitions that we absolutely need.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Ultimately, the proof of the pudding is in the eating

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: but many people will be watching.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: This is not something that are empty words anymore.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: It's too late for that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I have children, I have grandchildren. That's why I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: We have another question related to this subject. Let's hear it from Martin.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: How can people afford to be able to change to heat pump systems and electric cars, given the cost of these things?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: This comes right to the heart of what you were talking about, Tim, and Caroline. Paul Scully, let's start with you. How can people afford to do this?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Let's take the heat pumps, Â£5,000 subsidy grant towards putting them in but you don't have to put them in now.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: As Emily described it, it is a glide path to 2050.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It is when you are replacing your boiler.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: That's what I meant about driving markets.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I'm sorry, just sticking to heat pumps, that was the question. The cost is 7 to 10,000 pounds.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: The subsidy from the government is 5,000 pounds.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Is that enough for you, Martin --

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I'm not asking him to put it in tomorrow.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Similar power has gone down 89 percent.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: You start a market, show businesses that government are backing this kind of technology, businesses have the confidence for the next 10, 20, years they can pile in, invest money.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: The net zero strategy that we launched two weeks ago is looking at seeking to leverage Â£90 billion worth of private money into developing all these kind of technologies and creating new markets which, incidentally, will create jobs

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: and there's a business opportunity there.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: So that's when you get that perfect landing point, when you can actually -- instead of the kind of businesses that Emily was talking about exploiting people, can exploit things for the common good.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: How can people afford these? That's the question.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: I think it is a limp response.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It is inadequate.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Of course people need to be able to change.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Most of us heat our homes through gas

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: but also most of us don't have sufficient insulation.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: So it is all very well getting a heat pump, but if all the heat is going out the window anyway, we need to have both.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Make sure homes are properly insulated, make sure we change the way in which we heat our homes.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Quite frankly, I think it is a huge shame that over the last 10, 20 years there has been a change in policy

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , when I was in the department for energy and climate change, we had a policy of trying to make sure we insulated homes up and down the country.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: The government cut that scheme, introduced another one which has, frankly, been pathetic.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: We had a million homes built in the last few years that haven't been properly insulated.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: They will need to be retro fitted.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: So we need to be putting much more into heat pumps

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , of course we do, to make sure people can have them.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: We need to regulate new homes to make sure they are built properly

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , we need to put the money into insulation.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It is not sexy talking about insulating your loft

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , but that is the sort of things people need to do.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: How will anybody, even if they can afford an electric car, what's the point if you can't charge it? People don't want to go halfway up a motorway and run out of electricity.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: It doesn't work.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: They are not putting the money into the infrastructure.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: They are all talk and not doing it sufficiently seriously.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: The woman at the back.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: A lot of this comes to the cost of the person.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Being in Eastleigh we're close to an airport and a station which have fantastic ability to get anywhere.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: But if I wanted to go to Edinburgh, I can't get there for Â£30 on a flight.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: If I used the train it would be well over Â£100.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I want to drive to be green

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , but that choice is taken away from me.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: The same is I would love to have an electric car

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: but I live in a terraced house.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: A friend of mine has an electric car and suffers very regularly with juice anxiety.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Juice anxiety?

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Juice anxiety. It's a thing.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: It is not getting any better, saying it twice.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: He drives around and I have had a late night call saying "Can I come to your house and charge my car on the plug because I may not be able to get back home".

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: The charging units are out of order.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: There might be somebody in the unit charging their car, having a coffee, and he is waiting.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: So I don't think in this area there is enough chargers.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I would love an electric car

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , but I don't want to suffer right now with juice anxiety.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Tim.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Especially if you had to take someone to hospital or in an emergency go a long distance.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: This comes back to my point about the gap between ambitions and where we are, the affordability.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: If we all tomorrow ran out and bought an electric car

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , which we couldn't afford to do

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , how would we charge them?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: We'd run it off the grid.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: If we all switched from petrol to electrification, where is that going to come from?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: So the infrastructure also has to catch up in order to match our ambitions.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I'm not saying it can't be done

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: because the point is in the long run, as has been said, you build a market for something

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: so eventually, in theory, green technology could end up guaranteeing us not just abundant energy

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: but also cheaper energy that's cleaner, cheaper than fossil fuels

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: because it is on tap and it's renewable.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: So in the long run it will be great.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: But in the short term there is a cost.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: And it is to be borne by the consumer.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I would remind people over the summer, before we even put our heating on, many people's -- my electric bill almost doubled.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: That's the cost that's going to be put on to the consumers.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: How do we bridge that gap?

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Here's an idea, let's ban private jets.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I agree with Tim. I don't agree with much more that Tim said in the sense that there are political choices about where you put the cost for this transition.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Clearly, you do not put that cost on people who are unable to pay it.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: So when you go back to the discussion about the insulating your home or putting the heat pumps in your home, what the government should have put in the strategy was government money.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Governments borrow pretty cheaply right now and it needs to invest in order to reap rewards afterwards.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: Someone mentioned COVID.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: If you look at how much the government has spent paying people to be on furlough, that's about 100 billion a year.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: That has put the economy on ice but it hasn't achieved anything very positive beyond making sure that people could keep going.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: If we put that money, that kind of money into the transition to a green economy, it would create many, many jobs.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It would begin to pay for itself as those jobs raise the taxes that go back to the Treasury.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We can do this.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: I think what is so frustrating, look at some of the countries in Europe who are already working out mass transit

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , public transport schemes, we should have a vision that isn't looking at petrol cars and thinking how do we replace all of those with electric cars

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: because the building of cars is energy-intensive.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We need more manualisation among public transport schemes.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: The person at the back was saying she would love to use the train but it is more expensive than flying.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: That is a policy choice the government made.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It could make a different choice.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: It could tax the fuel domestically and make transport more affordable.

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: We know how to do this stuff. What we need to do is a prime minister who isn't giving the green light to a coal mine

nodes.speaker: Caroline Lucas
nodes.text: , isn't planning Â£27 billion on the biggest road ever, but is serious about investing in the economy.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: I agree with most of this.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: In 2014, the International Energy Agency was saying the electric vehicles would be at the same cost as the combustion engine by 2050.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We're getting to that in 2024/25.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: 60 percent of the energy can now be done green at a cheaper cost than the fossil fuel

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: if we just put the right policies in place.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: In the world we still have 500 billion against fossil fuel.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Many governments have put more money to the fossil economy than to the green economy.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: It doesn't have to cost more money.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: That is just a fallacy.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: By the way, when we invented the light bulb, it didn't work right away either.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: When we invented the computer, it didn't last more than one minute, you had to recharge them.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We are well beyond that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: Coming to the people itself, everything we do is not because of climate change

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , it is to ensure that everybody can have a decent life.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We're doing this for inclusion.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We're doing this for climate justice, equity and respect.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: So when we put a policy in place, like carbon pricing, which is absolutely needed, we should put the money we get from carbon pricing and be sure that the people who haven't seen their income move up in the last 3 or 4 decades don't have to pay a penny more but are better off

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: so we don't have the yellow jackets in the street.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: If the government look at it holistically, 90 or 100 percent of these can be solved.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: It is the same for business.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We should stop competing with each other on the future of humanity, include in politics

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , and start working together like adults on these things for the benefit of mankind.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We have the technology.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: We know what we have to do, and we don't have time.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul, thank you. I'm going to move on. We could talk about climate change all evening

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: , it is a massive topic, hugely important.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: There's another question a lot of you submitted this evening. I'm just picking one of them.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Can a racist term ever be defined as banter?

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: What you are talking about here is the furore there's been over Azeem Rafiq who claims he was subjected to institutional racism at his club, and he clearly feels that this has not been handled properly

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: and Yorkshire has carried out its own investigation, ruled no disciplinary action would take place, called it banter.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Tim.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The answer is no.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: There's nothing else to say.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I don't see how the club can explain its decision to not take further action other than, I suppose, hypothetically, perhaps, there was a reluctance to do something that might damage the career of a star player.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: But that's purely speculative.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: No, that particular term is totally unacceptable.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I'm going to explain what the term is.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: I don't need to cause offence.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: It is the P word, spelled P-A-K-I.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: He found it hugely offensive.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: It is hugely offensive. It was always hugely offensive.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Sometimes when people use the banter defence, they mean "I saw it used on a 70s sitcom".

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: People use it all the time.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I haven't caught up and I didn't know.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Actually, all that sort of language was considered offensive to tell the truth because it was offensive because it is derogatory.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: There's no possible explanation for it.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: I'm not astonished the language is being used

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: , I'm astonished such an august institution like that, critical to English sport, would behave in such a way.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: The answer to your question is no.

nodes.speaker: Tim Stanley
nodes.text: Never.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: I don't think I have a great deal more to add apart from this, which is British kids whose heritage is from the -- south Asia, are very often really, really keen on cricket.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: You see loads of kids of Asian heritage playing cricket.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: For a cricket club that is hoping to be, you know, as good as it possibly can be, to alienate huge amounts of talent like that

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: because of racism is alienating those youngsters who should be embraced by the club, just because that's the right thing to do

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: , but also the club is doing a grave injustice because they are not getting these talented kids.

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: To override talent by racism is never going to help anyone.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul Scully, looking at this in the light of day, the findings have yet to be revealed in full, it does seem baffling.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: What do you think is going on here?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I couldn't tell you.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I'm someone of south Asian heritage

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , my father was Belize.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I'm peal skinned

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , I had those words thrown at me at school.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: How --

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I shrugged it off as banter.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It was someone there. I'm not saying it as someone who had it as bad --

nodes.speaker: Emily Thornberry
nodes.text: Did you think it was banter at the time?

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: As I was getting older, I sensed it more.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: What you find is that it was always wrong.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It's thrown around -- I mean, to suit people of dark coloured skin

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , in the 70s, for example, a Bangladeshi being called that name.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: They had just gone through a civil war.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: And, you know, with the -- these other countries. Dividing it in that way is terrible.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: Coming forward now, no, it is absolutely not right.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: It cannot be called banter

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: , it must be called out

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: and we must do more to be sure it is being called out.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: I'm glad action is being taken.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: One of the people is not going to be selected.

nodes.speaker: Paul Scully
nodes.text: But we need to do more.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Paul Polman, you don't live here

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: , but I'm thinking in terms of your role as head of Unilever, a massive multi-national company, this must be an issue you have also dealt with.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: You don't need to live in the UK or anywhere

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , this is a global issue.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: My daughter-in-law who lives in the UK is from Singapore

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and she has to deal with this every week.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: She is a lawyer in London

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: and it is totally intolerable.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: She deals with it

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: but there is an underlying issue that goes much deeper

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: that I think is in every culture coming up where hate is being spread

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , where social media doesn't work in our favour

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , and we have to fight that.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: If we stay silent

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , we become complicit.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: In the US we have been very strong in rallying the CEO's together to rally when democracy was undermined on 6 January

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , when a President makes racial remarks

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , or whether there are remarks against communities.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: If we don't speak up against people that have these type of opinions that undermine the basic values of humanity

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , we move the boundaries in a very dangerous way.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: If you are a CEO of a company or in any position of power

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: , society actually expects you to speak up.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: And this is difficult for some people.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: They tend to take the safe route or the easy way out or to keep silent.

nodes.speaker: Paul Polman
nodes.text: That's not acceptable, in my opinion, when it gets to these fundamental issues of dignity and respect, equity, compassion, that really are at the roots of making humanity function.

nodes.speaker: Fiona Bruce
nodes.text: Caroline.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Paul put it absolutely beautifully.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I have little to add. I think the issue of complicity is an important one.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: Sometimes you think what difference can I make when this is going on

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: and standing up and speaking out and speaking truth and not being complicit is something we can all do

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , whether it is something we are overhearing on a train or if it is happening in a sports place or anywhere else.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: So I think there is a responsibility on all of us.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I do find the way the Yorkshire cricket club handled this -- the way it dismissed it as not a big deal.

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: I want to give a shout-out to the campaign Hope Not Hate that is standing up for this

nodes.speaker: Public
nodes.text: , running a campaign right now about getting racism out of sport, out of British life altogether.
